lessons.title: Lesson 1: Introduction to Number Systems (Natural, Whole, Integers)

games.name: Number System Sorter
games.implementationDetails: Use draggable div elements for numbers and drop areas for categories (Natural, Whole, Integers). Store numbers in an array. Use the Drag and Drop API. Check the number's value against category rules on drop. Provide visual feedback (color change) for correct/incorrect placements. Display a score.

games.name: True/False Number System Statements
games.implementationDetails: Create a game that presents true/false statements about the relationships between number systems. Provide feedback on the player's answers.
learningPoints: Relationships between Natural, Whole, and Integer Numbers

games.name: Number System Venn Diagram
games.implementationDetails: Use a canvas or overlapping divs to represent a Venn diagram. Create draggable number elements. Check the number's properties (positive, non-negative, integer) to determine the correct region. Provide visual cues for valid drop zones. Award points for correct placement.

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Rational Numbers and Their Representation

games.name: Rational Number Identifier
games.implementationDetails: Present a mix of numbers (fractions, decimals, square roots). Use buttons or a drag-and-drop interface. Check if the number can be expressed in p/q form (q!=0). Use Number.isInteger() and string manipulation. Provide feedback and a score.

games.name: Rational Number Builder
games.implementationDetails: Use input fields for p and q. Add validation (q!=0). Display the resulting rational number. Provide feedback if the input is valid. Have a score/timer component.

games.name: Equivalent Fraction Match
games.implementationDetails: Use a card matching game format (display a grid of cards). Store fraction pairs (one simplified, one not). Implement card flipping and matching logic. Check numerators and denominators after simplification. Timer and score elements.
learningPoints: Understanding different representations of the same rational number

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Finding Rational Numbers Between Two Given Numbers

games.name: Number Line Squeeze
games.implementationDetails: Use a canvas or SVG for the number line. Display two endpoints. Allow the player to add points between them using mouse clicks. Calculate the values of the new points. Provide visual cues for correct placement. Track accuracy and time.
learningPoints: Finding Rational Numbers Between Two Numbers

games.name: Rational Number Generator
games.implementationDetails: Use input fields for two numbers. Implement the mean formula ((a+b)/2). Display the generated number. Allow the player to generate multiple numbers between the previous result and the input. Display the generated sequence visually.
learningPoints: Finding Rational Numbers Between Two Numbers Using Mean Method

games.name: Fraction Comparison Challenge
games.implementationDetails: Display two fractions. Use input fields for the numerator and denominator of a third fraction. Check if the third fraction falls between the first two. Provide feedback (number line visualization). Score and timer.

games.name: Irrational Number Identifier
games.implementationDetails: Present numbers (√2, π, fractions, terminating decimals). Use buttons or drag-and-drop. Check if the number can be expressed in p/q form. Use Math.sqrt() and string manipulation. Provide feedback. Score points for correct answers, deduct points for incorrect.

games.name: Irrational vs Rational Drag and Drop
games.implementationDetails: Use draggable number elements and drop areas for 'Rational' and 'Irrational' categories. Store numbers in an array. Check number properties on drop. Give visual feedback and update score.

games.name: Square Root Approximation
games.implementationDetails: Use a number line (canvas or SVG). Display the square root symbol and a non-perfect square (e.g., √10). Allow the player to click on the number line to place a marker. Calculate the approximate value and compare to the correct value. Give feedback on accuracy.

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Real Numbers and the Real Number Line

games.name: Real Number Line Placement
games.implementationDetails: Use a number line (canvas or SVG). Allow the player to drag number labels (rational and irrational) and drop them on the line. Check for correct placement within a tolerance. Provide visual cues for valid drop zones. Score based on accuracy.
learningPoints: Relationship between Rational and Irrational Numbers

games.name: Which set does this belong to?
games.implementationDetails: Display a number. Use checkboxes or buttons for number system options (N, W, Z, Q, R). Store the correct sets for each number in a data structure. Check player's selections against the correct sets. Give feedback and award points.
learningPoints: Relationship between Rational and Irrational Numbers

games.name: Number System Hierarchy Quiz
games.implementationDetails: Present true/false or multiple-choice questions about subset relationships (e.g., 'Is Q a subset of R?'). Store questions in an array of objects (question, answer). Display questions and options. Check the answer and provide feedback.

lessons.title: Lesson 6: Locating Irrational Numbers on the Number Line (e.g., √2, √3)

games.name: Geometric Construction Simulator
games.implementationDetails: Use a canvas element to represent the number line. Implement virtual compass and straightedge tools using mouse events. Guide the player through the construction steps (draw line, mark point, draw semicircle, etc.). Provide visual feedback (highlight correct elements, show error messages). Use the Pythagorean theorem to calculate lengths. Check if construction is precise within a tolerance.

games.name: Approximate location identification
games.implementationDetails: Display a number line with tick marks. Show an irrational number (e.g., √5). Ask the player to select the closest tick mark. Calculate the approximate value and compare it.

games.name: Construction steps sequencer
games.implementationDetails: Store the construction steps in an array. Display the steps in a random order. Allow the player to drag and drop the steps into the correct sequence. Provide feedback on the order.

lessons.title: Lesson 7: Decimal Expansions of Rational Numbers (Terminating & Non-Terminating Recurring)

games.name: Decimal Expansion Classifier
games.implementationDetails: Present decimal expansions (use string manipulation to generate recurring decimals). Use buttons or drag-and-drop for 'Terminating' and 'Non-Terminating Recurring'. Check the pattern of the digits. Provide feedback.
learningPoints: Relationship Between Rational Numbers and Decimal Expansions

games.name: Fraction to decimal conversion
games.implementationDetails: Use input fields for p and q. Implement long division using JavaScript (consider limiting the number of steps). Display the decimal expansion. Provide visual cues for the repeating block (if any).

games.name: Divisibility rule identifier
games.implementationDetails: Present fractions (p/q). Ask the player to identify if the denominator's factors cause terminating expansion. Use multiple-choice options for rules. Check the prime factorization of q.

lessons.title: Lesson 8: Converting Decimal Expansions into p/q Form

games.name: Decimal to Fraction Converter
games.implementationDetails: Display a terminating or recurring decimal. Use input fields and buttons to guide the player through the algebraic steps (multiply by 10, 100, etc., subtract equations). Check each step for correctness. Provide hints and feedback.
learningPoints: Converting Terminating Decimals to p/q Form
Converting Non-Terminating Recurring Decimals to p/q Form

games.name: Missing step identifier
games.implementationDetails: Display the steps of the conversion process with one step missing. Use multiple-choice options for the missing step. Store the steps in an array. Check the player's selection. Provide feedback.
learningPoints: Converting Terminating Decimals to p/q Form
Converting Non-Terminating Recurring Decimals to p/q Form

games.name: Equation builder
games.implementationDetails: Display the decimal. Use input fields to create equations (e.g., 10x = ..., 100x = ...). Check if the equations are correctly set up to eliminate the recurring part. Guide the player with feedback.

lessons.title: Lesson 9: Decimal Expansions of Irrational Numbers (Non-Terminating Non-Recurring)

games.name: Decimal Expansion Identifier (Irrational)
games.implementationDetails: Present decimal expansions (generate random non-repeating digits or use pre-defined irrational numbers). Use buttons or drag-and-drop. Check for non-terminating and non-recurring patterns. Provide feedback.
learningPoints: Identifying Irrational Numbers from Decimal Expansions
Distinguishing Rational and Irrational Decimal Expansions

games.name: Construct an irrational decimal
games.implementationDetails: Provide a text input field. Give the player instructions (e.g., enter 10 digits that don't repeat). Check the input for patterns or repetition. Give feedback on the player's construction.
learningPoints: Identifying Irrational Numbers from Decimal Expansions
Distinguishing Rational and Irrational Decimal Expansions

games.name: Is this pattern irrational?
games.implementationDetails: Present different digit patterns (repeating, non-repeating, etc.). Use buttons or multiple-choice options ('Irrational', 'Rational', 'Cannot be determined'). Check if the pattern will result in a non-terminating, non-recurring expansion. Provide a explanation.

games.name: Real Number Operation Challenge
games.implementationDetails: Present expressions (e.g., 2 + √3, √5 - 1, √2 * √3). Use input fields or buttons to select the result of the operation. Implement basic simplification (if applicable). Check for correct answers.

games.name: Result set identification
games.implementationDetails: Present an operation (e.g., rational + irrational). Use buttons or multiple-choice options ('Rational', 'Irrational'). Check the rules for operations with real numbers. Provide explanation

games.name: Property identifier
games.implementationDetails: Present an algebraic manipulation (e.g., a + b = b + a). Use multiple-choice options for properties (Commutative, Associative, Distributive). Check the expression against property definitions.

lessons.title: Lesson 11: Representing √x Geometrically on the Number Line

games.name: Geometric Root Constructor
games.implementationDetails: Use a canvas. Allow the player to draw lines and circles (simulating compass and straightedge). Guide the player through the construction steps (step-by-step). Check for correct geometric relationships using the Pythagorean theorem. Provide visual feedback.

games.name: Step sequencer
games.implementationDetails: Display construction steps (text descriptions or images) in random order. Allow the player to drag and drop them into the correct sequence. Store the steps in an array with the correct order. Check the player's sequence.

games.name: What will be length?
games.implementationDetails: Present the construction diagram with certain lengths labeled. Ask the player to calculate other lengths using the Pythagorean theorem. Use input fields for the answers. Check numerical accuracy.

games.name: Identity Match Game
games.implementationDetails: Use a card matching format. Display expressions (e.g., (a+b)²) on one set of cards and expanded forms (e.g., a² + 2ab + b²) on another. Implement card flipping and matching logic. Check algebraic equivalence.

games.name: Missing term identifier
games.implementationDetails: Display an identity with one term missing (e.g., (a + b)² = a² + __ + b²). Use multiple-choice options for the missing term. Check the player's selection against the correct expansion.

games.name: Expression builder
games.implementationDetails: Present a square root identity (e.g., (a + b)²). Provide input fields for a and b. Ask the player to construct the expanded expression using the identity.

games.name: Rationalizing Steps Sequencer
games.implementationDetails: Display steps for rationalizing a denominator in random order. Use drag and drop to arrange the steps. Store the correct sequence in an array. Check the player's sequence.

games.name: Correct multiplier identification
games.implementationDetails: Present an expression with an irrational denominator. Use multiple-choice options for the correct multiplier (conjugate). Check the player's selection.

games.name: What changed?
games.implementationDetails: Display an expression before and after rationalization. Highlight or ask the player to identify the term(s) that changed. Compare the numerators and denominators.

lessons.title: Lesson 14: Laws of Exponents for Real Numbers

games.name: Exponent Law Match
games.implementationDetails: Use a card matching format. Display expressions with exponents on one set of cards and simplified forms (using the laws of exponents) on another. Flip cards and check equivalence
learningPoints: Laws of Exponents for Real Numbers

games.name: Missing exponent identifier
games.implementationDetails: Display an expression with a missing exponent (e.g., x^2 * x^__ = x^5). Use an input field or multiple-choice options for the missing value. Check if input is correct.
learningPoints: Laws of Exponents for Real Numbers

games.name: Law Application identifier
games.implementationDetails: Present an exponential expression. Use multiple-choice options for which law can be applied (Product Law, Quotient Law, Power Law, etc.). Check if the selected law is applicable.
